body.p: A survey was conducted to see how many phone calls people made daily. The results are displayed in the table below:
How many of the people surveyed make less than 9 phone calls daily?

response.feedback: There are 3 frequencies that are less than 9. However, we want the number of people, not the number of frequencies.
There are 8 numbers that are less than 9. However, we want the number of people who made less than 9 calls daily.
Nine represents the number of people who made 9 or more (at least 9) calls daily. We want the number of people who made less than 9 calls daily.
Correct. The frequencies between 1 and 8 calls add up to 27, 16 + 11 = 27.
You have counted the number of people who made 9 or less calls daily. We want strictly the number of people who made less than 9 calls daily.
Incorrect. Look at the frequencies instead of the number of phone calls made.
Incorrect. This is the average number of people surveyed across the five categories. You want the total number of people.
Correct. The total number of people surveyed is found by adding up all the frequencies: 16 + 11 + 5 + 3 + 1 = 36 people.
Incorrect. If you multiplied the average number of calls by the frequencies and added them together, you found the total average number of calls instead of the total number of people.
